Description:
***** THIS IS AN AWARD NOTICE, NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITION *****
This procurement is being concluded following a competitive quote exercise.

Brief Description of Requirement


This is a new request and there have been no recent procurement activities in this field. 
As part of the urban systems strategy and net zero places work, we are considering all opportunities for innovation and trying to create a picture to understand the gaps and opportunities which will inform where Innovate UK could support and act to help to achieve UK goals and drive growth.
The urban systems team within Innovate UK consider all impacts on people in the urban environment and how we can achieve net zero places and smarter cities.
The scope of the report is to look at the UK and only look at global activity from a benchmarking perspective.
Exclude the provision of wastewater services
Scope should pertain to the areas outlined below; specific outcomes are detailed in section 2 of this document.
The report should be completed by 31st March 2022.

Title: Town Centre Audits and Health Checks
Description:
The London Borough of Redbridge (LBR) aims to support businesses overcome the challenges caused by socialising restrictions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic,  and also wants to ensure that businesses in Town Centres can re-open or restart their commercial activity in a  successful way. The Council aims to identify the functions which each town centre provides for visitors and locals residents, including civic, health, social and leisure services, as well as retail and hospitality. 
To understand the strengths and opportunities of each town centre, the Council seeks to commission a thorough analysis of current consumer demand and supply factors, an examination of how town centre support programmes can enhance the prosperity of the town centres, how the development of local stakeholders groups can support the delivery of town centre actions plans and a refresh of the  Health Checks carried out in the borough's town centres in previous years.

Title: TD1749 - Provision of Community Based Family Support Services
Description:
The Council is looking to procure an innovative community-based service to support children, young people and families (the Service Users). 

The service will work using strengths-based methods with families to enable them to build on their skills and develop their own strategies to manage difficulties; enabling them to manage difficult periods in their lives. The overall aim of this community-based approach is to support children, young people and their families to develop skills and coping mechanisms to increase positive family functioning and build family resilience.

The Service Provider will work with families with multiple and complex needs, including poor school attendance/attainment, unemployment, involvement in crime or anti-social behaviour, domestic abuse, health issues and children who need help and those experiencing or at risk of experiencing neglect. The Service Provider will work with families to enable them to build upon their strengths and develop strategies to prevent breakdown.  

Please note, suppliers wishing to express interest and obtain the documentation, must do so as soon as possible. It is recommended that you express interest and obtain the documentation well before the submission  deadline to allow sufficient time to prepare and submit a comprehensive response. 

The deadline for returns is 10am on 21st January 2022. 

Please visit the Council's e-tendering system https://www.eastmidstenders.org where you can express interest and obtain the documents, (please note we will only accept expressions of interest through the e-tendering system). Please search for TD1749.

Title: 13304 - Demolition and associated Works for low rise residential maisonettes based at Sparkbrook, Birmingham B11 - AWARD
Description:
Demolition and associated Works of :
      1 - 25 (flats) ALFRED ROAD SPARKBROOK BIRMINGHAM B11 4PB 
      11 - 35 (flats) BEACH ROAD SPARKBROOK BIRMINGHAM B11 4PG 
      
      Acivico (Building Consultancy) Ltd on behalf of Birmingham City Council invites organisations to be considered to receive tender documentation for the demolition and associated works including site clearance of former Council's low rise residential based at Sparkbrook, Birmingham B11. 
      
      These buildings are no longer considered suitable and have been identified for demolition as part of proposed future site clearance and redevelopment of the area.
      This work is to consist of a safe demolition and site clearance including safe removal of asbestos materials both non notifiable and notifiable, prior to the building being demolished. The site must be well secured by use of specified fencing at the end of contact and complete any appropriate accommodation works during and at end of contract.
      
      The contractor must provide a suitably trained workforce and must have experience / knowledge of works required to be undertaken. The contractor will be responsible for providing their own power, water and welfare to undertake this work. It is expected in their tender submission, contractors will take due account of the covid- 19 implications regarding working on site in accordance with the latest CLC/Government/HSE or any other appropriate guidelines.
      The contract works have been programmed to commence around 13th September 2021 and be completed by 17th December 2021.
      
      BCC will be using its e-tendering system (in-tend) for administration of this procurement process and providers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. 
      
      The web address is https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc. Registration and use of in-tend is free. All correspondence for this procurement process must be via the in-tend correspondence function. If you are unable to register with in-tend please either email us at cps@birmingham.gov.uk or call 0121 464 8000.
      
      If you are interested in tendering please click on the following link to access Birmingham City Councils tender portal: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register as a bidder. We will send you a log on and password so you can download the tender documentation. 
      
      Requests to participate must be by way of completion and return of the tender documentation no later than 12:00 (GMT) on Friday 23rd July 2021 using the Supplier Portal.
      
      OPEN session: Wednesday 7th July 2021 between 10:00 - 12:00 by appointment. Covid regulations to be observed.

Title: ADC - Food Hygiene Inspection Services - AWARD
Description:
Arun District Council (ADC) is seeking to procure a contractor to undertake food hygiene food inspections (official Food Controls), on behalf of ADC at businesses identified by ADC.  Required services are detailed throughout this specification document and will include (but not be limited to) full inspections, partial inspections, and audits in accordance with latest version of the Food Standards Agency's Food Law Code of Practice England. These requirements shall be conducted in accordance with the aforementioned legislation in a format that adheres to the relevant legislation and ADC's requirements.
      
      Inspections will be conducted within Arun District councils' area on behalf of the Council.
      The number of inspections per annum required of the Contractor shall be variable. However, the Contract shall provide for undertaking a minimum number of 100 inspections per annum and the overall number expected to be completed shall range between 100 and 250 per annum.  The Contractor shall be required to respond flexibly to the demand for inspections and as instructed by the Council and which shall be paid for in line with the submitted pricing schedule.

Once in the tender there are five tabs - 'Tender', 'ITT - documents', 'Correspondence', 'Clarifications' and 'History'. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under 'Tender Details' continue to scroll down to the heading 'Tender Documents Received' where you will be able to view / download the documents.
      
      Please download all the documents and read very carefully.
      
      Opting In and Opting Out
      Please note you are required to 'Opt In' before you can access the 'My tender Return' to start populating your response. 
      
      The 'Opt Out' functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision.
      
      You can choose to 'Opt In' at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to 'Opt Out'.
      
      Further Guidance
      In addition, guidance on how to participate in a tender - download and upload documents / returns and if required, register your company (free of charge), can be found on the In-tend site under the 'Help' or 'Information for Suppliers' buttons.
      
      Receiving Notification Emails
      To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk`  to your Safe Senders list.

Organisation Name: Greater Birmingham & Solihull Local Enterprise Partnership
Title: Creative Industries Low Carbon Consultancy
Description:
The Creative Industries sector will need to achieve full decarbonisation by 2041 to align with the region's 2041 Net Zero carbon target laid out in #WM2041. There are a number of challenges to decarbonize certain elements of the sector, including transport, buildings, festivals/events and supply chains. However, the adoption of low carbon approaches in the sector can also be an enabler of growth by offering businesses an opportunity to pivot their business models to align with an area of significant growth, to tap into new branding opportunities, and to participate in regional innovation.

The West Midlands has natural sector strengths in both the Creative Industries sector, and the Low Carbon sector, and through collaboration and co-ordination there is an opportunity for the region to demonstrate its leadership in these areas and the synergies between them. Both nationally and regionally, there are a number of examples of businesses and projects within the Creative Industries sector that have adopted or encourage the adoption of low carbon approaches. However, to-date the state of the sector's adoption of Low Carbon is poorly defined.

The Greater Birmingham & Solihull Local Enterprise Partnership (GBSLEP) requires a supplier to provide a research study into the adoption of low carbon approaches within the West Midlands' Creative Industries. The research will support GBSLEP and other policymakers in defining the current state of the sector's progress with respect to Net Zero and inform the development of an implementation plan for the region's Creative Industries.

HOW TO APPLY
Please submit an electronic copy of your tender document to procurement@gbslep.co.uk by no later than 10th January 2022 by 23:59

Tender Documents can be found here:
https://gbslep.co.uk/tenders/tender-opportunities/12/creative-industries-low-carbon-consultancy/
Attachments: Supplier Questions  Clarifications Creative Low Carbon.xlsx

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH OF ENGLAND PROCUREMENT SERVICES
Title: Primary Care Based Mental Health Services including IAPT in East Sussex 21.794
Description:
This notice is to inform the market of the direct award of a 24-month contract to Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust for the provision of Primary Care Based Mental Health Services including IAPT in East Sussex for NHS East Sussex Clinical Commissioning Group ('the CCG') commencing 1st April 2022.
East Sussex Primary Care Based Mental Health Services consists of two core and integrated components. The first of which is the provision of Primary Care Mental Health Workers (PCMHW).
PCMHW are qualified mental health professionals that provide support to all GP practices in East Sussex. Their role is to support practices to manage patient care and enable timely directed access to appropriate mental health clinical, recovery and support services.
This includes advising on and assessment of referrals to the second component of the service, the Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT), programme.
The IAPT programme is a long standing nationally mandated programme for the treatment of adult anxiety disorders and depression. The national expectation as set out in the NHS Long Term Plan is that the number of people with anxiety disorders or depression who can access talking therapies through IAPT increase by an additional 380,000 per year to reach 1.9 million by 2023/24. IAPT services are characterised by three things, evidenced-based psychological therapies, routine outcome monitoring and regular outcomes focused supervision of staff providing the service. 
The provision of Primary Care Based Mental Health Services including IAPT are a nationally mandated duty for CCGs to provide.

The CCG has directly awarded this 24 month contract to Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, to enable the current service to achieve the Mental Health Five Year Forward View IAPT expansion access standards, and facilitate nationally mandated Community Mental Health transformation objectives.
This will provide additional time for the CCG to complete and embed the necessary transformation work and to understand better and accurately specify, the new EWS framework to facilitate consideration of future opportunities, for provision of its functions as the Transformation Programme completes its journey.
Contact Address 1: Sackville House, Brooks Close (please send any comms electronically to ensure receipt)
Additional Text:
Please note: NHS England and Improvement have announced that the Sussex Health and Care Partnership, which is made up of all health and care organisations across East Sussex, West Sussex, and Brighton and Hove, has successfully met the criteria to become an Integrated Care System (ICS). An ICS is a way of working across health and care organisations that allows them to work more closely together, to take collective responsibility for the health and wellbeing of populations across large areas.
It is not anticipated that the statutory responsibility or accountability of the individual health and care organisations working as an ICS will be affected, save for the expectation that CCG organisations will be abolished and functions transferred to the ICS. As a result of these intended healthcare reforms, the Contracting Authority currently NHS East Sussex CCG, may change during the life of the contract.

Title: London and Quadrant Housing Trust - Architects (London) Framework 2021 - 2025 - AWARD
Description:
London and Quadrant Housing Trust and its subsidiary Quadrant Construction Services are one of the largest providers of affordable housing in the UK, housing over 250,000 people in more than 95,000 homes, primarily across London and the South East of England. London and Quadrant Housing Trust are tendering for the provision of Architects for London and Quadrant's Self Delivered New Build Projects to comply with the Public Contracts regulations 2015. The objective of this tender process is to establish a Framework Agreement with the tenderers and London and Quadrant Housing Trust. The dates and contract value are estimates and could be subject to change. This tender is for Service providers/Consultants only.
      
      This is a two stage tender and both stages adhere to the time-scales as prescribed within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 for Restricted Find a Tender (FTS) Tenders.
      
      Stage 1: Selection Stage
      
      Click on the 'Express Interest' Button at the bottom
      
      Click on the 'Selection Stage' Tab at the top
      - Scroll to the bottom of the screen and you will be able to view the Tender Documents and access the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - For the Selection Stage you will only need to submit the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - We will score your questionnaire and will advise you as to whether you are successful or not
      
      
      ONLY IF YOU HAVE PASSED THE SELECTION STAGE 
      
      Stage 2: ITT Stage
      
      - Click on the 'ITT' Tab 
      - Scroll to the bottom and you will be able to access the Tender Documents
      - Tenderers will be briefed as to what they will need to submit for this tender
      
      Please allow sufficient time to submit your return by the specified dates as late returns will not be permitted. 
      
      
      Under the Framework Agreement L&Q and all companies within the L&Q Group (including, without limitation, Quadrant Construction Services) will have the option to call-off contracts with individual framework contractors as and when required. In addition, other Social Housing Providers in the UK (both those that are in existence now and those that may be in existence in the future) will also be entitled to call-off contracts under the Framework Agreement. "Social Housing Provider" for this purpose means any provider of social housing and includes, without limitation, Registered Providers, Local Authorities and ALMOs. Such Social Housing Providers will only be entitled to call off under the Framework Agreement if L&Q consents.
      
      For information regarding this tender please contact the Framework Team via the tender portal. This tender is managed by the Group Procurement department. Please do not contact any other department within the London and Quadrant Group.

Title: St Helens Council Synthetic Pitch Maintenance 2022
Description:
St Helens Council is seeking a supplier to provide maintenance of 9 synthetic pitches over 8 different sites around St Helens including 4 School Sites: 
4 visits per year per pitch: 3 monthly intervals
•	The Removal of debris and leaves from surface. 
•	Sweeping of the surface using a rotating brush and integral mounted rigid brush. 
•	Decompaction of the top 5-8mm of sand or top 10-15mm of rubber infill (as necessary). 
•	Deep Cleaning of the infill, removal of fine contaminates and dust, filter, utilising a vibrating sieve, allowing clean particulate to redress the synthetic surface. 
•	Re-distribution of the clean particulate to provide even coverage. 
•	Repair of up to 5 linear metres of restick (as necessary) 
•	Dead Weed Removal to perimeter of surface. 
•	Maintenance Site Report - carried out on every visit by our Technician. 
•	Facility Survey Report - carried out annually by our trained Assessor 
•	Full secure online access to all maintenance reports, surveys and other documentation

Title: EV076 Killingworth Depot 11. Wall Cladding Works - Detail Design, Supply & install Block F
Description:
EV076 Killingworth Depot 11. Steel Cladding Works - Detail Design, Supply & install Block F

The Authority has secured funding from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to support delivery of the Killingworth Site Sustainable Retrofit Project. This project is a combination of refurbishment and replacement of existing office accommodation, workshop, welfare and other facilities on the site ensuring it 'future proofs' depot operations. Energy efficiency and functionality are key principles, and the Project will use a wide range of energy efficient, generation and storage/distribution solutions to support a move to an electric powered operational fleet whilst reducing the site carbon footprint. This procurement opportunity relates specifically to Block F Vehicle Maintenance Workshop Refurbishment and North Tyneside Council will act as Principal Contractor for the project, therefore tenderers should note that they will be working in the capacity of Sub-Contractor. Tenderers must be aware that this is an operational building and as such works must be undertaken taking into consideration the ongoing workshop operations which will require work phasing and innovative delivery solutions to ensure disruption to the service is kept to a minimum. We expect tenderers to liaise closely with the service and out of hours and weekend working will at times be necessary. The Block F site is very restrictive for access / plant movements and therefore it is strongly recommended that Tenderers undertake a site visit, contact details to make arrangements are contained within the Preambles document in the tender pack. Tenderers will be required to confirm that they will comply will the Authority's minimum standards in relation to health & safety and mandatory training requirements. All operatives must hold CSCS cards, relevant training certification and any other trade/task specific relevant qualifications. This package is anticipated to be completed in 6 weeks the full programme is expected to be delivered between 31 March 2022 and 31 October 2022.
Additional Text: As soon as you express an interest, the tender documents become available to download. The direct link to the opportunity is: https://procontract.due-north.com/Advert?advertId=e4ffd59c-3404-ec11-810d-005056b64545

Organisation Name: Cheshire west and Chester Borough Council
Title: People who Harm support services
Description:
Cheshire West and Chester Council require a People who Harm Programme (PWH) to address harmful behaviour within an intimate relationship across the borough. Commissioning this programme will help to ensure the development and maintenance of healthy relationships by supporting participants to take responsibility for their actions and ensure they are motivated to change. Programme support will provide insight and skills that are integral to maintaining healthy relationships. 

The People who Harm Programme should be for males who harm and who are aged 18 and over and should be voluntary for individuals to access. There is an equitable offer, for women who harm, that is conducted through Early Help and Prevention Service. National statistics suggest male people who harm is more prevalent. This has formed the basis of why a male only service is required at this moment in time.   

The current delivery takes a groupwork approach to challenging attitudes and behaviours whilst providing a supportive approach to positive change. The council would like to seek innovative ways this can be delivered in the future to ensure maximum outcomes are met.  

The Council seeks an experienced provider to work with people who harm and ensure that early identification and interventions are delivered through the borough. 

The Council intends to commission a provider for a two-year contract with an option to extend for a further 12 months if required.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [TLC: Talk, Listen, Change|M16 9EZ|NONE||Yes|No]

Title: SCC - XA - RFQ - PPM Training
Description:
Surrey County Council (SCC) manages and delivers hundreds of programmes and projects per annum, at times these can vary in consistency and quality which can lead to sub-optimal delivery. A recent internal PPM review has resulted in a new PPM Methodology, which is based on best practice and aligns in principle to APM & Prince2. The next step is to embed this into the culture at SCC, which may require an organisation-wide training programme and other culture changes, such as discussion, forums, etc. 
      
      The Surrey PPM methodology, also referred to as The Surrey Way, is available to all staff but we need key colleagues to recognise the importance, value and accessibility of the methodology when delivering programmes and projects of various sizes, including the adaptability of tools and techniques. Key roles include Accountable Executives, Senior Responsible Owners, Programme Managers, Project Managers.

Title: Provision of three purpose-built modular clinical rooms for Mid and South Essex for Respiratory disease diagnosis and management
Description:
This is a Contract Award Notice to communicate a contract award made by the Contracting Authorities; NHS Thurrock Clinical Commissioning Group (as lead Commissioner), NHS Castle Point and Rochford Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Basildon & Brentwood Clinical Commissioning Group, NHS Southend Clinical Commissioning Group, and NHS Mid Essex Clinical Commissioning Group (hereinafter referred to as "the Authority") in compliance with their local SFI's.

The contract award is made to Clinicabin Ltd for the provision of three purpose-built modular clinical rooms for Mid and South Essex for Respiratory disease diagnosis and management.

This contract is for a period of two years commencing 1st March 2022, at a total aggregate contract value of £128,340 (excluding VAT) equalling £154,008 (including VAT). The term may be extended for a further 12 months. 

The CCG is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020) for spend above £25,000.

Title: Home Based or Community Short Breaks Framework
Description:
Tenders are invited for inclusion on the framework for provision of Home Based or Community Short Breaks.  

Short Breaks form part of a continuum of Services that support disabled children, young people aged 0-18, and their families and are provided to give:

•	Disabled children and young people enjoyable experiences away from their primary carers, thereby contributing to their personal and social development, reducing social isolation and their overall wellbeing.
•	Parents and carers a necessary and valuable break from their caring responsibilities.

The aim of this Service will be to provide specialist group and 1:1 support at home or out in the community to disabled children and young people so that they are able to enjoy activities in these environments and spend time away from their parents/carers so that they are able to have a break from caring also.

There is an annual budget of £250,000.00. There may be additional spend directly from Customers via Direct Payments.

There will be and initial term of two years plus options to extend for a further two years in annual increments. 

Please note suppliers wishing to express interest and obtain the documentation must do so by 11.30pm on Thursday 13/01/2022. It is recommended that you express interest and obtain the documentation well before this time to allow sufficient time to prepare and submit a bid. 

The deadline for returns is 10.00am on Friday 14/01/2022. 

Documents are available at www.eastmidstenders.org 

Please search for TD1770.

Please note: we will only accept expressions of interest through the e-tendering system.

Description:
Dear Sir/Madam,
      
      In accordance with the Hampshire Building Minor Works Framework you are invited to tender for the New Appliance Bay Doors at Totton & Kingsclere Fire Stations and have been supplied with the attached documents.
      
      Please download all the documents and read VERY carefully.
      
      Opting In and Out
      Please note you are required to 'Opt In' before you can access the 'My tender Return' to start populating your response. 
      
      The 'Opt Out' functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision.
      You can choose to 'Opt In' at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to 'Opt Out'.
      
      Please note - The site visit requirements in item 2.0 of the schedule of works must to be arranged in advance with myself or Bowie Heer.
      
      Your tender return documents are to include the following 6 documents:
      1. Completed Grand Summary Sheet
      2. Completed form of tender
      3. Fully priced schedule of works (Section 3 of tender specification)
      4. Breakdown of all preliminary costs
      5. Completed electrical tender summary (from within Appendix A)
      6. Completed resource questionnaire (From appendix V of the PCI document)
      
      Your completed tender return documents (as outlined above) should be submitted via In Tend no later than 2pm on Tuesday 18th January 2022.
      
      Kind regards
      
      Mark Willcocks

Title: Sheerness Revival: Levelling-Up Fund business case development - A855
Description:
Swale Borough Council is inviting Expressions of Interest to quote for development of its Levelling-Up Fund business case. 

The contract will involve developing an evidence base, business case narrative and economic modelling in support of the development of a Levelling-Up bid focussed on Sheerness, as well as the co-ordination of design and feasibility work undertaken by other consultants and which will inform the required business case. 

The contract shall commence on 14 February 2022 and terminate on 15 April 2022. The council may extend the opportunity for a further period of no more than eight weeks, subject to government guidance regarding submission timescales. The bidder/s who submit/s the Most Economically Advantageous Quotation will be awarded the contract. 

Expressions of Interest and the Request for Quotation (RFQ) document must be submitted / uploaded on the Council's e-procurement portal. The closing date for submission of Expressions of Interest and the closing date for the RFQ is Monday 7 February 2022 at 12noon

Title: 2897/LM - Autism Spectrum Support Services provider for Students
Description:
The University of Sheffield is looking for a provider of support for students and relevant, appropriate communication with DDSS. Covering 4 key areas:
1.	One-to-one Specialist Study Skills Support & Mentoring for students on the autism spectrum.
2.	Organisation and facilitation of 'the autism social group' - an informal support group. 
3.	Production and submission of specific invoices and timesheets on a monthly basis.
4.	Specific communications and related services to the university.

The Disability & Dyslexia Support Service (DDSS) is based within Student Support Services. DDSS offers a student-centred support approach, and achieves this through close liaison with other support services, academic departments and external agencies. 

Currently the University has almost 5,000 students who have declared a disability, with over 3,000 actively supported by DDSS.

The full technical specification can be found in the ITT documentation, which will be available after you have expressed your interest on In-Tend. 

Tender Process and Documentation:
This is an Open exercise under the Light Touch regime. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield
If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender, they must be submitted via the In-tend System.
Your tender response must also be submitted through InTend to arrive by the date and time specified. Late tenders will not be considered.

Closing date for receipt of bids: 20th January 2022 at 12 Noon (UK time).

Title: Perpetrator Engagement Worker
Description: Sheffield City Council are looking to improve outcomes for adults with multiple disadvantages by using a joined-up and person-centred approach through the Changing Futures Programme. These adults could be experiencing a combination of homelessness, substance misuse, mental health issues, domestic abuse, and contact with the criminal justice system. Part of Sheffield City Council's delivery approach includes a core team of case workers to engage and work with service users intensively and the provision of bespoke interventions to domestic abuse perpetrators and victims with complex needs, including where there are allegations of mutual abuse.  Local data intelligence suggests there is a cohort of around 200 people who are already known to services in Sheffield who would be eligible to be part of the Changing Futures Programme.

Title: Tier 2 Adult Weight Management
Description:
Public Health England have awarded Local Authorities a ring-fenced grant to procure tier 2 weight management programmes. Tier 2 weight management programmes for overweight or obese adults are multi-component programmes that aim to reduce a person's energy intake and help them to be more physically active by facilitating behaviour change. The intention is to commission provision of a range of tier 2 weight management programmes that runs for 12 months up until December 2022. This programme must deliver the three components of a Tier 2 Weight Management Programme; diet, behaviour change and physical activity.

The Public Health England grant is for local authorities to commission a new or expand upon an existing weight management service. In Merton there is currently no tier 2 weight management service and this will therefore be commissioned as new.

Organisation Name: The Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead Council
Title: Arboricultural Works Framework for The Royal Borough of Windsor & Maidenhead
Description:
The Royal Borough of Windsor & Maidenhead is setting up a Framework for the provision of
arboricultural services within The Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead for both
standard, time sensitive and emergency work. Work will be required along the public
highway (which must be carried out in accordance with the requirements of Chapter 8 of the
Traffic Signs Manual and further detailed in the booklet entitled "Safety at Street Works &
Road Works" issued by the Department for Transport; the New Roads and Street Works Act
1991, The Traffic Management Act 2004 and Traffic Management Permit Scheme (England)
Regulations 2007 and any subsequent amendments thereto), on public rights of way and on
sites within Borough such as cemeteries, churchyards, parks, open spaces and property
sites.
There are 30,299 individual trees recorded on the adopted highway, in parks, open spaces
and cemeteries within RBWM. The Authority is currently in the process of completing an
audit and condition survey of trees in some of these sites and estimates a further 5,000 trees
will be added to our records. In addition, the Authority manages a number of small
woodlands and hedgerow trees.
The Authority is firmly committed to maintaining the trees and woods as a vital part of the
environment of The Royal Borough of Windsor & Maidenhead, the policies and guidance for
which are contained in 'A Tree and Woodland Strategy for the Borough 2010 to 2020'. This
document can be viewed at https://www3.rbwm.gov.uk/download/downloads/id/203/tree_
strategy_and_policy_guidance.pdf
The proposed Framework will play a key part in helping to deliver the aims and objectives of
the Tree and Woodland Strategy for the Authority. The tree related services that will be
required by the Authority include:
• Climbing Inspections
• Formative Pruning
• Crown Lifting
• Crown Thinning
• Pruning Back From Property, Boundaries Or Objects
• Crown Reduction and Reshaping
• Conservation Pruning
• Pollarding
• Re-Pollarding
• Cleaning Out Objects
• Severance/removal of Climbing Plants
• Removal of Dead, Dying, Diseased and Broken Branches
• Crown Clean
• Specific Branch/Limb Removal or Reduction
• Removal of Suckers and Epicormic Shoots
• Pruning for Infrastructure
• Bi-annual removal of Epicormic shoots, suckers and crown lifting
• Tree Felling
• Removal/Trimming of Hedges
• Coppicing
• Tree Stump and Root Removal or Treatment
• Young tree maintenance
• Root Pruning
• Bark Wound Repair
• Bracing and Propping
• The Provision of an Emergency Out of Hours Service
• Control of Brown Tail Moth
• Control of Oak Processionary Moth (excluding chemical treatment)
• Traffic Management
Additional Text:

and user details - Note the username you chose and click 'Save' when complete - You will
shortly receive an email with your unique password (please keep this secure).
For further guidance on how to register on The Public Sector Procurement Portal hosted by
Bravo Solution you can watch the video available via the following link -
http://www.screencast.com/t/o6NHgMNjnf?_ncp=1502113290076.897-1 Please note that
despite the Bravo Advantage 16 branding the instructions and guidance in the video are
correct and apply to the Public Sector Procurement Portal.
Express an Interest in the tender - Login to the portal with the username/password - Click the
'PQQs / ITTs Open To All Suppliers' link. (These are Pre-Qualification Questionnaires or
Invitations to Tender open to any registered supplier) - Click on the relevant PQQ/ ITT to
access the content. - Click the 'Express Interest' button at the top of the page. - This will
move the PQQ /ITT into your 'My PQQs/ My ITTs' page. (This is a secure area reserved for
your projects only) -You can now access any attachments by clicking 'Buyer Attachments' in
the 'PQQ/ ITT Details' box.
Responding to the tender - Click 'My Response' under 'PQQ/ ITT Details', you can choose to
'Create Response' or to 'Decline to Respond' (please give a reason if declining) - You can now
use the 'Messages' function to communicate with the buyer and seek any clarification - Note
the deadline for completion, then follow the onscreen instructions to complete the PQQ/ ITT
- There may be a mixture of online & offline actions for you to perform (there is detailed online
help available) You must then submit your reply using the 'Submit Response' button at the
top of the page. If you require any further assistance please consult the online help, or
contact the eTendering help desk on 0800 069 8630 or email help@bravosolution.co.uk

Title: International Evidence Gaps
Description:
The aim of this procurement is to provide the UKSA and BEIS with detailed information on international flows of finance and exports within the UK space sector. This will provide useful guidance as we work towards the goal of growing and levelling up our space economy, and using space to deliver for the UK and the world.

Objective: To fill evidence gaps (both internal and external) in our understanding of how international economic activity shapes the UK space industry and to use this information to develop a successful international strategy which sets out clear priority areas for engagement.

For a full description please see the attached document

Title: Electric Vehicle Charging Points Framework - AWARD
Description:
Hampshire County Council invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to be considered for selection to tender for the Electric Vehicle Charging Points Framework
      
      The Framework will commence on 6th April 2022 and will be for a period of four years.
      
      Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs on Tuesday 7th December 2021. 
      
      How to obtain the Tender Documents
      The Tender documents can be accessed when logged into In-Tend by selecting 'View Details' on the relevant tender advert and clicking the 'Express Interest' tab. Once in the tender there are five tabs - 'Tender', 'ITT - documents', 'Correspondence', 'Clarifications' and 'History'. Select the 2nd tab (ITT - documents) where you will find useful information under 'Tender Details' continue to scroll down to the heading 'Tender Documents Received' where you will be able to view / download the documents.
      
      Please download all the documents and read very carefully.
      
      Opting In and Opting Out
      Please note you are required to 'Opt In' before you can access the 'My tender Return' to start populating your response. 
      
      PLEASE NOTE you are required to 'Opt In' to view & complete the two Questionnaires for this project. 
      
      The 'Opt Out' functionality will also be available throughout the duration of the tender process. Opting out will give you the option of declaring you no longer want to receive any further communication in relation to this tender along with the opportunity of providing comments and feedback for this decision.
      
      You can choose to 'Opt In' at any time during the tender process if you initially decided to 'Opt Out'.
      
      Your completed 'Tender Return Document(s)' should be submitted via 'In-tend' by 2pm on Tuesday 7th December 2021.
      
      Further Guidance
      In addition, guidance on how to participate in a tender - download and upload documents / returns and if required, register your company (free of charge), can be found on the In-tend site under the 'Help' or 'Information for Suppliers' buttons.
      
      Receiving Notification Emails
      To ensure you receive email alerts and notifications from our system, please add the email domain `@in-tendorganiser.co.uk`  to your Safe Senders list.

Description: The Authority has secured funding from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to support delivery of the Killingworth Site Sustainable Retrofit Project. This project is a combination of refurbishment and replacement of existing office accommodation, workshop, welfare and other facilities on the site ensuring it 'future proofs' depot operations. Energy efficiency and functionality are key principles, and the Project will use a wide range of energy efficient, generation and storage/distribution solutions to support a move to an electric powered operational fleet whilst reducing the site carbon footprint. This procurement opportunity relates specifically to Block F Vehicle Maintenance Workshop Refurbishment and North Tyneside Council will act as Principal Contractor for the project, therefore tenderers should note that they will be working in the capacity of Sub-Contractor. Tenderers must be aware that this is an operational building and as such works must be undertaken taking into consideration the ongoing workshop operations which will require work phasing and innovative delivery solutions to ensure disruption to the service is kept to a minimum. We expect tenderers to liaise closely with the service and out of hours and weekend working will at times be necessary. The Block F site is very restrictive for access / plant movements and therefore it is strongly recommended that Tenderers undertake a site visit, contact details to make arrangements are contained within the Preambles document in the tender pack. Tenderers will be required to confirm that they will comply will the Authority's minimum standards in relation to health & safety and mandatory training requirements. All operatives must hold CSCS cards, relevant training certification and any other trade/task specific relevant qualifications. This package is anticipated to be completed in 12 weeks (multiple visits) the full programme is expected to be delivered between November 2021 - July 2022.
Additional Text: As soon as you express an interest, the tender documents become available to download. The direct link to the opportunity is: https://procontract.due-north.com/Advert?advertId=0836934d-c85d-ec11-8110-005056b64545

Title: Methane Analyser
Description:
The  University of Derby is currently running the De-Carbonise project to help SME's in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire increase their sustainability and save money by reducing energy costs and carbon emissions. The De-Carbonise team would like to buy a methane analyser to assist several SMEs on the project to ascertain the amount of greenhouse gases which are being emitted from their land. We want a piece of equipment that can analyse methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) fluxes between the soil and the atmosphere.

A portable unit will allow flexibility to test materials in-situ (avoiding disturbance) and help advise to the SME whether to reduce their emissions based on soil and land chemistry.

Essential outputs: 

•	Ability to analyse concentrations of methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) to a precision of at least 1ppb over 5 seconds for CH4, and 2 ppm over 5 seconds for CO2. 
•	Suitable for portable operation 
•	Maximum 15kg in weight (with batteries) for portable use in the field
•	Universal power supply
•	Battery life of at least 2 hours. 
•	Suitable for operation in the field: rugged/quality design, weatherproof, reliable.
•	Ability to measure soil flux, including relevant apparatus (eg. flux chambers. If the soil flux system is chamber-based, then it should be a good design with consideration of temperature and pressure effects etc.). It should also be able to work with custom chambers.
•	Have a practical and reliable means of downloading data from the device.
•	Be reliable for research level application, as evidenced by widespread adoption in the relevant communities of users.
•	Training provided to a minimum of 2 staff members.
•	Technical support, warranty and servicing provided for 1 year as a minimum. 
•	Delivery to University of Derby, Derby (DE22 1GB).

Desirable outputs: 

•	Measurement of any other gases relevant to soil ecosystem processes, such as O2 and N2O.
•	Static sampling option, with ability to analyse small sample sizes.
•	Suitable for long-term lab operation.
•	Network and/or USB (etc.) connectivity for monitoring and device management
•	Capacity for upgrade including the detection of other gases and use of different kinds of chamber etc.
•	Transparent flux chamber option so that photosynthesis is not interrupted.
•	Range of powering options for versatility
•	Programming interface for advanced automated operations
•	Delivery by February 2022 to Derby, UK.

If not an existing supplier please register as a prospective supplier. Guides and links to the registration process can be found here: https://www.derby.ac.uk/services/finance/procurement-suppliers-and-tendering/supplier-info/

Once registered (and for existing suppliers) the link to the University of Derby's Oracle portal and guides for Responding to Negotiations (Tenders/Quotes) via Oracle is here: https://www.derby.ac.uk/services/finance/procurement-suppliers-and-tendering/supplier-info/existing-suppliers/

Title: Enterprising Barnsley & DMC websites
Description:
During Covid 19, the Enterprising Barnsley service had to pivot and change its delivery method. With being a trusted source of information, we had to move from people mainly contacting us via phone, to an online web chat function and self help through a daily updated Covid Landing page. Whist the support we offered worked and businesses in the borough found it very useful, it became clear that due to the age of the website and issues with the original company who built it going out of business, it is no longer fit for purpose. In addition, we have the ambition to make sure any business in Barnsley can access some form of business support. Due to the cost of integration of the current model, this needs to build on the self service model we used during Covid 19. An LMS as well as making sure it is easy for companies to find information that is relevant to them quickly and effectively is key to this. 

It has been decided that a full rebuild of the current Enterprising Barnsley and DMC's websites is the best approach to achieve the outcomes we are wanting. Whilst doing this, it makes sense to refresh the visual brand of the Enterprising Barnsley service to bring it in line with the work done for the branding of the DMC's & the Seam. The work also needs to integrate a grant application portal which will allow businesses a smoother easier and clearer way of applying for a range of business support grants than the current process. This will also allow BMBC staff to be more efficient in the management of these grants, ultimately increasing productivity and reducing time for the support to reach the businesses. 

We are wanting a single log in to the website where businesses can log in and see all different grants they have applied for as well as the any learning they have undertaken on the LMS. This single log in will allow us to add in extra functionality in the future if more funding is secured to help improve the service we deliver even further. With this in mind, we would welcome the organisations bidding for the work to propose a road map of what additional features they feel could be integrated into the websites going forwards. 

This project is funded by a variety of grants including ERDF, Launchpad, Digital Innovation Grant, Business Productivity Programme, BMBC & Other contributors.

Title: HDC Design & Build of Horsham Skate Park - AWARD
Description:
Horsham District Council (the Council) invites tenders for the design and build of a Skate Park in Horsham Park.
      
      Horsham Skate Park was designed and built in 2001 with a strong input from the local skate and BMX community. The Skate Park saw users travel from all across the County to use its large wooden playground with a variety of features to suit the needs of all the disciplines.  Well attended 'Jams' were celebrated and remembered fondly, attracting large crowds from all across the south east over the Skate Park's initial 10 years. The Skate Park's current location, in the busy Horsham Park, has seen multiple design layouts over the past 19 years. Today's design features many large transitions and hips which support a thriving BMX and Scooter scene - and still attracts pro and sponsored riders from these disciplines. Whilst there is still attendance from local skateboarders, the riding surface of the flat areas has become uneven and rough and other local concrete options provide a better offer. 
      
      Horsham Park is the town's largest park and site for the swimming pool and leisure centre. The Skate Park is therefore used by a large cross section of age groups including toddlers and young children. As well as being situated amongst a busy Park, the Skate Park is five minutes walk from Collyer's, the town's Sixth Form College. This means the Skate Park is well populated by students throughout weekdays to 'hang out' as well as ride.
      
      The existing Skate Park is 1000m2 constructed in plywood on a tarmac surface.
      
      The outcome of this Tender is to identify and select a single Contractor to take the Project forward to a final design, including user consultation and a completed installed concrete Skate Park, to suit the needs of the local young people whilst taking into account a range of ages, abilities and wheels whilst taking into account the site constraints.

Title: CP2105-21 - Independent Assessments and Appeals for Blue Badge Applications
Description:
The aim of the Blue Badge scheme is to help people with severe mobility problems caused by visible and non-visible (hidden) disabilities to access goods and services, by allowing them to park close to their destination. 

Devon County Council is tendering for a contract for the provision of assessments by qualified professionals (Expert Assessors) to determine the eligibility of applicants with physical and non-visible (hidden) disabilities in accordance with the Department for Transport (DfT) Blue Badge scheme regulations, at centralised locations across Devon and also undertaking of Appeals following unsuccessful applications.  (*ensuring applicants do not need to travel further than 30 miles)

There will be a bidder event held via Microsoft Teams on 11th November 2021 at 10am in relation to this tender. The event will be focusing on the Tender Process and will explain the ITT and the other documents as well as useful information to enable Tenderers to be 'tender ready'. There will be an overview of the service requirement from commissioners of the service and there will be an opportunity to ask questions at the end of the event. Whilst every endeavour will be made to answer questions at this event, it may be necessary to respond at a later date. The presentations and questions and answers given will be made available via the Procurement Portal. To ensure that this event is of the most benefit, tendering organisations are encouraged to ensure that persons attending are the most appropriate i.e. persons who will be constructing and making decisions about any tender submitted. In order to book a place, please e-mail oliver.reed@devon.gov.uk  for the meeting invite to be sent to you.
